awd_titl_txt: Metal-oxo and Metal-peroxo Complexes in Oxidative Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Most chemicals derive from a just a few simple starting materials yet chemical synthesis has a major impact on the economy of the United States, contributing more than 30% of the Gross National Product (GNP).  In this project, with the support from the Chemical Catalysis (CAT) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor John Groves of Princeton University seeks to design new chemical processes to make high value chemicals.  The new synthetic methods may be used to make new drugs and agrichemicals.  The research combines laboratory experiments and computer calculations to predict and verify how the reactions progress.  The ultimate goal of this work is to replace expensive metal catalysts with less inexpensive metals that are more effective in convert carbon-hydrogen (C-H) bonds to carbon-fluorine (C-F) bonds.  This research illustrates the detailed pathways for the new chemical reactions.  The research group of Professor Groves trains future scientists, especially women and those that are under-represented in science.  These scientists gain both technical training and mentoring so that they are successful in careers in teaching, research, and industry.

More than 95% of industrially-produced chemicals are derived from a small slate of simple, molecular building blocks.  Chemical manufacturing contributes more than 30% of the GNP of the United States.  With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Groves of Princeton University is developing new methods for the catalytic oxygenation, fluorination and pseudo-halogenation of C-H bonds. Such processes are of fundamental interest as they inpact the economic value of the pharmaceutical, agrochemical and chemical process industries. The development of such novel oxidative processes requires a thorough understanding of the mechanisms of metal-mediated atom transfer.  The project aims to observe the unitary processes of catalysis by characterizing reactive metal oxo and metal peroxo intermediates and elucidating the nature of their reactions with organic substrates. In particular, the research elaborates a conceptual basis for heteroatom rebound catalysis (HRC), which can be dissected in a manner similar to hydrogen atom transfer. The project integrates small molecule chemical catalysts with insights from metalloenzymes and biocatalytic processes. Through analogies with Nature, the redox chemistry of iron, manganese, cobalt and other metals can add significantly to understanding and increased capabilities in chemical catalysis.  The Groves group at Princeton University trains students and postdoctoral research associates, especially under-represented minorities and women, through the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates Programs, the Girls Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics Summer Program (GSTEM), and Princeton Chemistry's summer diversity program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report – Metal-oxo and Metal-peroxo Complexes in Oxidative Catalysis

The goal of this program is to understand and harness the breadth of strategies for small molecule C-H activation chemistry currently being practiced by microorganisms, which use high-valent transition metal chemistry of abundant, first-row elements. Metalloenzymes mediate a vast array of oxidative C-H to C-X interconversions with exquisite selectivity, although their broad application has been hampered by generally short enzyme life spans. Insights derived from biological, synthetic and biomimetic systems have led to new catalysts and have defined a conceptual basis to understand these processes. Successes in this endeavor are already providing new methods of late-stage drug and agrochemical diversification, and metabolite identification, new opportunities for energy transduction using hydrocarbons, new concepts for the development of fuel cells and water oxidation and new processes for disinfecting bioterrorism agents. It is the central thesis of this program that recent conceptual advances in oxidative chemical and biochemical catalysis, as well as the interplay of experiment and theory, offer unprecedented opportunities to develop abundant transition metals as catalysts of these processes. Our approach involves direct kinetic and spectroscopic characterization of reactive metal-X intermediates under conditions of active, fast catalysis. Our goal is to reveal and extend the range of these catalytic systems that employ new entries into oxo- and halogeno-metal complexes, including new C-H oxygenation, fluorination, heteroatom and desaturation protocols.   

Broader Impacts.

 Broad application of this chemistry could have tremendous impact on the nation’s and the world’s chemical and energy economies. More than 95% of chemical industry products are derived from a small pallet of simple building blocks, predominantly through oxygenation, C–C bond formation, halogenation or amination. C-H bonds are ubiquitous in commodity chemicals, intermediates and end products, but current technologies for C-H transformations still lack sufficient generality and selectivity. Chemical processes account for ~10% of total global energy consumption (~42 EJ/year) and > 5% of global CO2 emissions. Direct CO2 emissions from primary chemical production, ammonia, methanol and high-value chemicals, were 920 Mt CO2 in 2020, representing a 2.1% average annual increase from 2015. Improvements in catalytic processes could result in up to 13 EJ/year in reduced energy use.

 

This project has helped train the personnel that are necessary for the nation to achieve the technological advances offered by these discoveries and the teachers of science for the future. Human health is impacted by the selectivity of chemical and biochemical catalysis that is necessary for the pharmaceutical industry to produce new and pure drugs and precursor molecules cleanly and efficiently. For example, catalytic processes can replace reagents that are toxic or explosive with more benign and less expensive catalysts such as iron and manganese. New catalytic technologies are also needed to allow the world economy to capture the vast resources of natural gas, which are now largely wasted, and to give high value added to petroleum feed stocks such as light hydrocarbons and olefins. New discoveries in oxidative catalysis are necessary to address these scientific, technological and environmental challenges such as reducing the huge energy burden of syngas production at very high temperatures.  

Graduate students, postdoctoral research associates and undergraduates being trained in the group, nine men and seven women during 2019-2023, gave presentations at a variety of national and international meetings. Five group members have accepted faculty positions over this period.

Intellectual merit. With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Groves of Princeton University has developed new methods for the catalytic oxygenation, fluorination and pseudo-halogenation of C-H bonds. During the last grant period there was significant progress in four inter-related areas:

(1) Mechanisms of heteroatom rebound catalysis to functionalize unactivated C-H bonds,

(2) Teaching non-heme manganese complexes to fluorinate C-H bonds,

(3) Exploring the newly-discovered reactivity of hydroxo-metal complexes and two-proton acidity,

(4) Exploring photoredox reactivity of novel cobalt complexes.

 Dr. Groves presented 14 invited lectures and seminars nationally and internationally and 13 research publications during 2019-2023.

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2024
Modified by: John T Groves
